Title: $f(0)=f'(0)=f'(1)=0$ and $f(1)=1$ implies $\max|f''|\geq 4$
Content: Let $f\in C^2(\mathbb [0,1],\mathbb [0,1])$ such that $f(0)=f'(0)=f'(1)=0$ and $f(1)=1$ Prove that $\max_{[0,1]}|f''|\geq 4$ Progress Applying Cauchy mean value theorem three times proves the existence of $\xi\in (0,1)$ such that $f'(\xi)=1$ $\eta\in(\xi,1)$ such that $\displaystyle f''(\eta)=\frac{1}{\xi-1} <0$ $\beta\in(0,\xi)$ such that $\displaystyle f''(\beta)=\frac{1}{\xi}>0$ If $\displaystyle \xi\leq \frac{1}{4}$ or $\displaystyle \xi\geq \frac{3}{4}$ , we're done. What about other cases ? I haven't used the continuity of $f''$ yet...
AcceptedAnswer:
Note that
$$f(1)=\int_0^1\left(\frac{1}{2}-t\right)f''(t)dt.$$
So
$$1\leq \left(\int_0^1\left\vert \frac{1}{2}-t\right\vert dt\right)\cdot \sup_{[0,1]}|f''|=\frac{1}{4} \sup_{[0,1]}|f''|.$$
and the desired conclusion follows.
